skills.name: Identify percentage increase multipliers where the percent is an integer
Identify percentage decrease multipliers where the percent is a multiple of 10
Identify percentage decrease multipliers where the percent is an integer
Calculate original value problems involving percentage increase where the percent is an integer
Work out the percentage rate in compound percentage increase problems

explanations.A: I think you have found the multiplier for increasing by 30%. We are decreasing by 30%.
explanations.B: Decreasing a number by 30% means you are left with 70% of that number (100% - 30% = 70%). To find 70% of a number you can multiply by 0.7, 70% = 70/100 = 0.7.
explanations.C: Multiplying by 30 will find you a number that is 30 times bigger it will NOT decrease a number by 30% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 30%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.D: Multiplying by 0.3 will find you 30% of a number BUT will not decrease a number by 30% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 30%? How would you write this as a decimal?

explanations.A: I think you have found the multiplier for increasing by 40%. We are decreasing by 40%.
explanations.B: Multiplying by 40 will find you a number that is 40 times bigger it will NOT decrease a number by 40% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 40%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.C: Decreasing a number by 40% means you are left with 60% of that number (100% - 40% = 60%). To find 60% of a number you can multiply by 0.6, 60% = 60/100 = 0.6.
explanations.D: Multiplying by 0.4 will find you 40% of a number BUT will not decrease a number by 40% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 40%? How would you write this as a decimal?

explanations.A: Multiplying by 0.34 will find you 34% of a number BUT will not increase a number by 34% . What percentage will you have in total if you increase a number by 34%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.B: We start with the whole number which is 100%. We then add on the increase of 34% to get 134% This is 1.34 as a decimal.
explanations.C: Multiplying by 34 will find you a number that is 34 times bigger it will NOT increase a number by 34% . What percentage will you have in total if you increase a number by 34%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.D: I think you have correctly identified that increasing a number by 34% is the same as finding 134% of a number BUT you have forgotten to convert this number to a decimal.

explanations.A: We start with the whole number which is 100%. We then add on the increase of 24% to get 124% This is 1.24 as a decimal.
explanations.B: Multiplying by 24 will find you a number that is 24 times bigger it will NOT increase a number by 24% . What percentage will you have in total if you increase a number by 24%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.C: Multiplying by 0.24 will find you 24% of a number BUT will not increase a number by 24% . What percentage will you have in total if you increase a number by 24%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.D: I think you have correctly identified that increasing a number by 24% is the same as finding 124% of a number BUT you have forgotten to convert this number to a decimal.

explanations.A: Multiplying by 0.06 will find you 6% of a number BUT will not decrease a number by 6% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 6%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.B: I think you have found the multiplier for increasing by 6%. We are decreasing by 6%.
explanations.C: I think you have found the multiplier for decreasing by 60%, but we are decreasing by 6%. What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 6%?
explanations.D: We have taken 6% away from our original 100% leaving us with 94% We then converted this into a decimal 0.94

explanations.A: Multiplying by 0.12 will find you 12% of a number BUT will not decrease a number by 12% . What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 12%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.B: We have taken 12% away from our original 100% leaving us with 88% We then converted this into a decimal 0.88
explanations.C: Multiplying by 0.76 will reduce a number by 24% (1 - 0.76 = 0.24 = 24%) NOT 12%. What percentage will you have left if you decrease a number by 12%? How would you write this as a decimal?
explanations.D: I think you have found the multiplier for increasing by 12%. We are decreasing by 12%.

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Toms use the number 200, increase 200 by 10% then increase this number by 10%. Next increase 200 by 20%, do you get the same number? Try substituting in a number to check Katie's statement.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Katie's use the number 200, increase 200 by 10% then decrease this new number by 10%, do you get back to the number you started with? Try substituting in a number to check Tom's statement.
explanations.C: Not quite. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Katie's use the number 200, increase 200 by 10% then decrease this new number by 10%, do you get back to the number you started with? Try substituting in a number to check Tom's statement.
explanations.D: If we increase a number by 10% we now have 110%. 10% of our new 110% is 11%, this added onto our new value is 121% NOT 120%, so Tom is incorrect. If we increase a number by 10% we now have 110%. If we find 10% of this new value that is 11%, this subtracted from 110% is 99% NOT 100% and so Katie is also incorrect

explanations.A: Not quite. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Paul's use the number 200, decrease 200 by 20% then decrease this number by 20%. Next decrease 200 by 40%, do you get a bigger or a smaller number?
explanations.B: Not quite. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Jo's use the number 200, increase 200 by 20% then increase this number by 20%. Next increase 200 by 40%, do you get a bigger or a smaller number?
explanations.C: If we increase a number by 20% we get 120%. Increasing 120% by 20% we get 144%, as 20% of 120% is 24%. 144% is more than 140% so Jo is correct. If we decrease a number by 20% we get 80%. Decreasing 80% by 20% we get 64%, as 20% of 80% is 16%. 64% is greater than 60%, therefore the original number has decreased by less, so Paul is correct.
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one person is correct. Try substituting in some numbers and calculating the percentages to see who is correct. For example: To check Jo's use the number 200, increase 200 by 20% then increase this number by 20%. Next increase 200 by 40%, do you get a bigger or a smaller number?

explanations.A: I think you have increased 200 by 25%, but the question is asking us to find the original number if after a 25% increase we get 200. If we are increasing the ★ by 25% what percentage of the star are we calculating? This percentage will be equal to 200, can you use this to find the value of the ★?
explanations.B: Not quite, remember our star (★) is 100%. Increasing 100% by 25% we get 125%. If we know that 125% = 200 how can we find 100%?
explanations.C: I think you have found 25% of 200 and taken this away from 200 BUT 25% of 200 is not the same as 25% of our original number, the ★. If we are increasing the ★ by 25% what percentage of the star are we calculating? This percentage will be equal to 200, can you use this to find the value of the ★?

explanations.A: I think you have increased 84 by 40%, but the question is asking us to find the original number if after a 40% increase we get 84. If we are increasing the ★ by 40% what percentage of the star are we calculating? This percentage will be equal to 84, can you use this to find the value of the ★?
explanations.B: Not quite, remember our star (★) is 100%. Increasing 100% by 40% we get 140%. If we know that 140% = 84 how can we find 100%?
explanations.D: I think you have found 40% of 84 and taken this away from 84 BUT 40% of 84 is not the same as 40% of our original number, the ★. If we are increasing the ★ by 40% what percentage of the star are we calculating? This percentage will be equal to 84, can you use this to find the value of the ★?
